org.opensha.data

Class DataUtils

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.opensha.data.DataUtils

  • public final class DataUtils
extends Object
    Utilities for operating on double-valued data.

    See Doubles minimum, maximum, sum, mean, product, etc... of double arrays as well as other properties

    Transformations of double arrays or Lists may be performed on empty data sets; null data sets throw an exception.

    TODO isPositive throws exception for size==0, check for consistency with transformations

    Class designed to reduce data copying hence why List variants do not call toArray() and delegate to varargs variant.

    Methods that return a result or infomration about a supplied data set will typically take a Collection<Double> as an argument, whereas methods that transform data in place will only take List<Double>s.

    Author:
    Peter Powers, Kevin Milner

      • WEIGHT_TOLERANCE

        public static final double WEIGHT_TOLERANCE
        Acceptable tolerance when summing weights and comparing to 1.0. Currently set to 1e-8.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • getPercentDiff

        public static double getPercentDiff(double test,
                    double target)
        Returns the difference between test and target, relative to target, as a percent. If target is 0, method returns 0 if test is also 0, otherwise Double.POSITIVE_INFINITY. If either value is Double.NaN, method returns Double.NaN.
        Parameters:
        test - value
        target - value
        Returns:
        the percent difference

      • positivize

        public static double[] positivize(double[] data)
        Ensures positivity of values by adding Math.abs(min(data)) if min < 0. Operation performed in place on supplied array.
        Parameters:
        data - to positivize
        Returns:
        a reference to the supplied data, positivized if necessary

      • isMonotonic

        public static boolean isMonotonic(boolean ascending,
                  boolean repeats,
                  double... data)
        Returns whether the elements of the supplied data increase or decrease monotonically, with a flag indicating if duplicate elements are permitted. The repeats flag could be false if checking the x-values of a function for any steps, or true if checking the y-values of a cumulative distribution function, which are commonly constant.
        Parameters:
        ascending - if true, descending if false
        repeats - whether repeated adjacent elements are allowed
        data - to validate
        Returns:
        true if monotonic, false otherwise

      • diff

        public static double[] diff(double... data)
        Returns the difference of adjacent elements in the supplied data. Method returns results in a new array that has data.length - 1 where differences are computed per data[i+1] - data[i].
        Parameters:
        data - to difference
        Returns:
        the differences between adjacent values

      • buildCleanSequence

        public static double[] buildCleanSequence(double min,
                          double max,
                          double step,
                          boolean ascending,
                          int scale)
        Creates a sequence of evenly spaced values starting at min and ending at max. If (max - min) / step is not equivalent to an integer, the last step in the sequence will be &lt;step. Unlike buildSequence(double, double, double, boolean), this method returns a sequence where any 'odd' values due to rounding errors have been removed, at least within the range of the specified scale (precision or number of decimal places).
        Parameters:
        min - sequence value
        max - sequence value
        step - sequence spacing
        ascending - if true, descending if false
        scale - the number of decimal places to preserve
        Returns:
        a monotonically increasing or decreasing sequence of values
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - if min >= max, step <= 0 , or any arguments are Double.NaN, Double.POSITIVE_INFINITY, or Double.NEGATIVE_INFINITY

      • buildLogSequence

        public static double[] buildLogSequence(double min,
                        double max,
                        double step,
                        boolean ascending)
        Creates a sequence of values starting at min and ending at max, the log of which are evenly spaced.
        Parameters:
        min - sequence value
        max - sequence value
        step - sequence spacing
        ascending - if true, descending if false
        Returns:
        a monotonically increasing or decreasing sequence where the log of the values are evenly spaced
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - if min >= max, step <= 0 , or any arguments are Double.NaN, Double.POSITIVE_INFINITY, or Double.NEGATIVE_INFINITY

      • indexAndSort

        @Deprecated
public static int[] indexAndSort(double[] data)
        Deprecated. 
        Sorts the supplied data array in place and returns an int[] array of the original indices of the data values. For example, if the supplied array is [3, 1, 8], the supplied array will be sorted to [1, 3, 8] and the array [2, 1, 3] will be returned.
        Parameters:
        data - array to sort
        Returns:
        the inidices of the unsorted array values
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - if source array is null

      • sortedIndices

        public static List<Integer> sortedIndices(List<Double> data,
                          boolean ascending)
        Returns an index List that provides a pointers to sorted data. Let's say you have a number of List<Double>s and want to sort them all according to one of your choosing. Supply this method with the desired data and use the returned indices view any of your arrays according to the sort order of the supplied data.

        Notes:

        • The supplied data should not be sorted
        • This method does not modify the supplied data in any way
        • Any NaNs in data are placed at the start of the sort order, regardless of sort direction

        Parameters:
        data - to provide sort indices for
        ascending - if true, descending if false
        Returns:
        an index List

      • nearestNeighborHist

        @Deprecated
public static DefaultXY_DataSet nearestNeighborHist(double[] data,
                                               double origin,
                                               int size)
        Deprecated. 
        Nearest neighbor binning algorithm after Silverman, B. W. (1986), Density Estimation for Statistics and Data Analysis, Chapman & Hall, New York. This method is a density estimator that uses variable width binning with a fixed sample size per bin that better reflects the distribution of the underlying data. It is particularly useful when workgin with power-law distributed data. Bin widths are computed as the difference between the last values in adjacent bins. In the case of the 1st bin, the supplied origin is taken as the "last value" of the previous bin. Bin positions are set from the median value in each bin. Note that the supplied data is not modified; this method uses a copy internally. In most cases, data will be fairly continuous in X, however, for small sizes it's possible to have bins of identical values such that corresponding bin value is Infinity. Such values are not included in the resultant data set.
        Parameters:
        data - to be binned
        origin - for binning
        size - of each bin
        Returns:
        an XY_DataSet of the binned distribution or null if the binned distribution is empty
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - if the supplied data is null
        IllegalArgumentException - if supplied data is empty, the bin size is <1, or the origin is greater than all data values

      • median

        public static double median(double[] unsorted)
        Parameters:
        unsorted -
        Returns:
        median of the array of values. if values are already sorted, use median_sorted

        Parameters:
